ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: As a seminar, questions relating to assignments/workload aren't applicable.

This is a tricky course to evaluate since we had a different speaker every week. Overall the clarity with which main concepts were explained differed fromweek to week, but I appreciate that all the presenters were very responsive to audience questions and encouraged students to be engaged in the talks.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Introduction to researchers outside of Yale.
The seminar format made it easy to engage. Good presenters and laid back format. The snacks gave the room the right atmosphere.

I enjoyed getting to see how the methods I'm learning in my current coursework are applied across a wide range of different research questions. I also really liked how welcoming the speakers were towards audience questions and comments.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: No specific need for improvement.

Often there were parts of the talks that I couldn't follow because the methods were too advanced. However, I view this as a lack of background on my part rather than a flaw in the course, and I understood enough to find most lectures informative and enjoyable.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: n/a
NA

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Provides exposure to research that I am interested in getting involved with. Helpful to see what people at different campuses across the US are doing.
n/a
I am studying energy economics for my thesis, so this course was a good overview of the larger environmental economics landscape within which my research is nested.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: same as above
To expose myself to more environmental economic research
Wanted to take a natural resources economics class. This course was a seminar, and did not require a significant amount of work outside class time.
My advisor told me about the course, and it sounded interesting and relevant to what I'm studying.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes.

That answer depends on your expectations. I still don't understand many of the methods employed by the speakers, but I wasn't necessarily expecting too. However, I do have a better idea of what it'slike to defend your research in front of a critical audience, and I have developed a familiarity with the types of questions that audience members often ask. I also picked up some good tips on presenting/communication styles by observing how different speakers chose to convey their material.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Good lecture series but material is at advanced level, so would not be appropriate for those just getting into environmental economics.
Take this class.
Go ahead and take it. It's not much work, and you'll get to hear about some really interesting research. The course is also good preparation for being a presenter yourself.
